title: Icons of Italian Automotive Style Struggle to Go Electric
abstract: Ferrari and Lamborghini are trying to design battery-powered cars that inspire the same devotion as their costly internal combustion models.
byline: By Jack Ewing and Federico Borella

multimedia.caption: Lamborghinis parked at the company’s factory in Sant’Agata Bolognese, Italy.
Lamborghinis parked at the company’s factory in Sant’Agata Bolognese, Italy.
Lamborghinis parked at the company’s factory in Sant’Agata Bolognese, Italy.

title: ‘An Invisible Cage’: How China Is Policing the Future
abstract: Vast surveillance data allows the state to target people whose behavior or characteristics are deemed suspicious by an algorithm, even if they’ve done nothing wrong.
byline: By Paul Mozur, Muyi Xiao and John Liu
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
org_facet: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China

multimedia.caption: Surveillance cameras set up in April at a residential compound in Mudanjiang, Heilongjiang Province.
Surveillance cameras set up in April at a residential compound in Mudanjiang, Heilongjiang Province.

title: The Leader of the QAnon Conspiracy Theory Returns
abstract: Three posts on Friday night signaled the resurfacing of a figure who used a variety of conspiracy theories to marshal support for Donald J. Trump.

multimedia.caption: A QAnon flag above the crowd along the National Mall at an Independence Day celebration in Washington in 2019.

title: The Work of Online Volunteers
abstract: Moderators’ work on Reddit and Facebook is crucial but not paid. We should be creative in how we compensate them.

title: Can Dual-Use Solar Panels Provide Power and Share Space With Crops?
abstract: Companies like BlueWave are betting on it. But the technology has its critics.

title: CRISPR in the Classroom
abstract: A new generation of scientists is growing up with CRISPR technology. Here’s how some high school students learn to edit genes.

title: NASA’s Return to the Moon Starts With Launching a 55-Pound CubeSat
abstract: NASA has grandiose plans for sending astronauts back to the moon. Those start with a microwave-size private spacecraft about to lift off.

multimedia.caption: An artist’s concept of the CAPSTONE spacecraft orbiting the moon, where it will spend at least six months on its primary mission.
An artist’s concept of the CAPSTONE spacecraft orbiting the moon, where it will spend at least six months on its primary mission.
An artist’s concept of the CAPSTONE spacecraft orbiting the moon, where it will spend at least six months on its primary mission.

title: “一个无形的牢笼”：中国如何管控未来
abstract: 各地警方正在采购能够收集大量监控数据的技术，以预测犯罪和提前干预。相关系统和软件针对的是那些在算法和当局看来行为或特征可疑的人士，即便他们是无辜的。
byline: By Paul Mozur, Muyi Xiao and John Liu
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
org_facet: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China

multimedia.caption: 北京一根路灯柱上的监控摄像头。
北京一根路灯柱上的监控摄像头。

title: Companies Are More Vocal Than Ever on Social Issues. Not on Abortion.
abstract: The corporate response to the Supreme Court’s Friday decision was more muted, and the companies that did speak out mostly talked about their health care policies.
byline: By Emma Goldberg and Lora Kelley
des_facet: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)

multimedia.caption: Disney executives told staff that the company would help employees access affordable health care “including pregnancy-related decisions” if it wasn’t available in their location.

title: Meta clamps down on internal discussion of Roe v. Wade’s overturning.
byline: By Mike Isaac and Ryan Mac

multimedia.caption: Managers at Meta reaffirmed a May memo that said that “discussing abortion openly at work has a heightened risk of creating a hostile work environment.”

title: Ken Knowlton, a Father of Computer Art and Animation, Dies at 91
abstract: His work at Bell Labs in the 1960s laid the groundwork for today’s computer-generated imagery in film and on TV.

multimedia.caption: Ken Knowlton, left, and his Bell Labs colleague Leon Harmon. Behind them is the computer-generated artwork they created in the mid-1960s titled “Computer Nude (Studies in Perception I).”
Ken Knowlton, left, and his Bell Labs colleague Leon Harmon. Behind them is the computer-generated artwork they created in the mid-1960s titled “Computer Nude (Studies in Perception I).”
Ken Knowlton, left, and his Bell Labs colleague Leon Harmon. Behind them is the computer-generated artwork they created in the mid-1960s titled “Computer Nude (Studies in Perception I).”

title: Juul Users Prepare to Say Goodbye to Their Vape of Choice
abstract: After a Food and Drug Administration ruling against the company, fans of the brand said they appreciated its simple design. “I definitely will miss the Juuls,” a leather worker in Detroit said.

multimedia.caption: Juul, once the top e-cigarette brand, faced a number of lawsuits in recent years, before the F.D.A. announced its order against the company this week.

title: App Rules Are Twisted to Absurdity
abstract: It’s not just you — what you can buy on your phone makes less and less sense.

title: The Rise of the 0.5 Selfie
abstract: These selfies, taken with an ultra-wide-angle lens, aren’t fussed over. Sometimes they are just “distorted and crazy.”

title: As Midterms Loom, Elections Are No Longer Top Priority for Meta C.E.O.
abstract: Mark Zuckerberg, who once said securing elections was “the most important thing,” has shifted Meta’s focus to the metaverse. That may have real-world implications.
byline: By Sheera Frenkel and Cecilia Kang

multimedia.caption: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, has been focused on pushing his company into the immersive world of the metaverse.
Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, has been focused on pushing his company into the immersive world of the metaverse.

title: Many Russian Cyberattacks Failed in First Months of Ukraine War, Study Says
abstract: A report published by Microsoft also found that Moscow’s disinformation campaign to establish a narrative of the war favorable to Russia was doing better than expected.
byline: By David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes

multimedia.caption: The Microsoft account of cyberattacks and disinformation campaigns by Vladimir V. Putin’s government showed that only 29 percent breached the targeted networks.
The Microsoft account of cyberattacks and disinformation campaigns by Vladimir V. Putin’s government showed that only 29 percent breached the targeted networks.

title: Gadgets Were Hot. Now They’re Not.
abstract: Not long ago, it seemed impossible to find a laptop. The pandemic has upended that, too.

title: Should You Buy Now, Pay Later? Tread Carefully.
abstract: Afterpay, Apple and other financial tech companies are popularizing installment plans for paying off shopping splurges. These programs can also cause confusion and a loss of control.

title: A Big Step Toward Fusion Energy Is Hailed by a Seattle Start-Up
abstract: Zap Energy said its experimental reactor core was ready for a milestone test. Skeptics routinely question whether the technology is currently possible.

multimedia.caption: Zap Energy, fusion energy start-up in Seattle, said it had successfully primed a new and more powerful reactor core.
Zap Energy, fusion energy start-up in Seattle, said it had successfully primed a new and more powerful reactor core.

title: The Avatars Wear Prada
abstract: And Balenciaga and Thom Browne. Meta opens a new fashion store for the metaverse. Should you shop?

title: Meta Agrees to Alter Ad Technology in Settlement With U.S.
abstract: The Justice Department had accused Meta’s housing advertising system of discriminating against Facebook users based on their race, gender, religion and other characteristics.

multimedia.caption: Meta’s headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif.
Meta’s headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif.

title: Closing Arguments Made in Trial of Elizabeth Holmes’s Ex-Boyfriend
abstract: The fraud trial of Ramesh Balwani, the chief operating officer of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, is heading to a verdict soon.

multimedia.caption: Ramesh Balwani, the former chief operating officer of Theranos, arriving in court in San Jose, Calif., on Tuesday.

title: MapQuest and Other Internet Zombies
abstract: Some online stars from our past just won’t die.

title: Microsoft Plans to Eliminate Face Analysis Tools in Push for ‘Responsible A.I.’
abstract: The technology giant will stop offering automated tools that predict a person’s gender, age and emotional state and will restrict the use of its facial recognition tool.

multimedia.caption: “We’re taking concrete steps to live up to our A.I. principles,” said Natasha Crampton, Microsoft’s chief responsible A.I. officer.

title: Can Natural Gas Be Used to Create Power With Fewer Emissions?
abstract: One company says it has the technology. And though investors looking for cleaner power generation are lining up, some environmentalists are skeptical.

multimedia.caption: At NET Power’s test plant in La Porte, Texas, arrows show the flow of carbon dioxide. For 12 years, the company has been working on technology that uses natural gas to create electricity without emissions.

title: Why You Might Buy Your Next Car Online
abstract: Tesla shifted to selling cars entirely online in 2019. Now, some established automakers, like Ford, are talking about taking a similar approach.

multimedia.caption: Rachel Ryan, who lives near Los Angeles, bought a Tesla Model Y last year. Tesla’s success selling its vehicles online could force other automakers to follow suit.

title: Google Says It’s Time for Longtime Small-Business Users to Pay Up
abstract: Google is charging some small businesses for email and other apps after more than a decade of free use. Business owners say Google is being callous.

abstract: Roughly two-thirds of employees at the store in Towson, Md., voted to join the union.

title: Bitcoin Plummets Below $20,000 for First Time Since Late 2020
abstract: Its fall was accelerated in recent weeks by the collapse of two major cryptocurrency projects while sowing doubts about the stability of the overall cryptocurrency market.
